cards.name: Akroma, Angel of Wrath
cards.text: Flying, first strike, vigilance, trample, haste, protection from black and from red
cards.flavor: "Wrath is no vice when inflicted upon the deserving."

rulings.text: The "legend rule" cares about legendary permanents with the exact same English name. You can control Akroma, Angel of Wrath and Akroma, Angel of Fury at the same time.

foreignNames.name: 怒りの天使アクローマ

cards.originalText: Flying, first strike, vigilance, trample, haste, protection from black and from red

cards.name: Akroma's Vengeance
cards.text:
Destroy all artifacts, creatures, and enchantments.
Cycling {3} ({3}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
cards.flavor: "Many must die for the one who should not have perished."

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

cards.originalText:
Destroy all artifacts, creatures, and enchantments.
Cycling {3} ({3}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)

cards.name: Angelic Page
cards.text:
Flying
{T}: Target attacking or blocking creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: If only every message were as perfect as its bearer.
cards.originalText:
Flying
{T}: Target attacking or blocking creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Armageddon
cards.text: Destroy all lands.
cards.originalText: Destroy all lands.

cards.name: Auramancer
cards.text: When Auramancer enters the battlefield, you may return target enchantment card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: "In memories, we can find our deepest reserves of strength."
cards.originalText: When Auramancer enters the battlefield, you may return target enchantment card from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: Cloudshift
cards.text: Exile target creature you control, then return that card to the battlefield under your control.
cards.flavor:
"Even storm clouds bow to worship Avacyn."
—Elder Rimheit

rulings.text: Once the exiled permanent returns, it's considered a new object with no relation to the object that it was. Auras attached to the exiled permanent will be put into their owners' graveyards. Equipment attached to the exiled permanent will become unattached and remain on the battlefield. Any counters on the exiled permanent will cease to exist.
The returned card won't be the target of any spells or abilities that targeted it before. Any spells that don't target, such as Akroma's Vengeance, will still affect it.
If a token is exiled this way, it will cease to exist and won't return to the battlefield.

When an effect returns the exiled card "under your control," you control it indefinitely after that. In a multiplayer game, if a player leaves the game, all cards that player owns leave as well. If you leave the game, any creatures you control from Cloudshift's effect are exiled.

cards.originalText: Exile target creature you control, then return that card to the battlefield under your control.

cards.name: Congregate
cards.text: Target player gains 2 life for each creature on the battlefield.
cards.flavor:
"In the gathering there is strength for all who founder, renewal for all who languish, love for all who sing."
—Song of All, canto 642

rulings.text: Creatures are counted during resolution.

cards.originalText: Target player gains 2 life for each creature on the battlefield.

cards.name: Darien, King of Kjeldor
cards.text: Whenever you're dealt damage, you may create that many 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens.
cards.flavor:
"With his dream of unification fulfilled, Darien became the last king of Kjeldor. Those who followed were known as the kings of New Argive."
—Kjeldor: Ice Civilization

rulings.text: If you're dealt damage that causes your life total to become 0 or less, you lose the game before the tokens can be created.

foreignNames.name: キイェルドーの王、ダリアン

cards.originalText: Whenever you're dealt damage, you may create that many 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens.

cards.name: Dauntless Cathar
cards.text: {1}{W}, Exile Dauntless Cathar from your graveyard: Create a 1/1 white Spirit creature token with flying. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.
cards.flavor: "The harder they try to extinguish my faith, the brighter it burns in the darkness."
cards.originalText: {1}{W}, Exile Dauntless Cathar from your graveyard: Create a 1/1 white Spirit creature token with flying. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.

cards.name: Decree of Justice
cards.text:
Create X 4/4 white Angel creature tokens with flying.
Cycling {2}{W} ({2}{W}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Decree of Justice, you may pay {X}. If you do, create X 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you'll draw a card.
A mana cost of {X}{X} means that you pay twice X. If you want X to be 3, you pay {8}{W}{W} to cast Decree of Justice.

cards.originalText:
Create X 4/4 white Angel creature tokens with flying.
Cycling {2}{W} ({2}{W}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Decree of Justice, you may pay {X}. If you do, create X 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens.

cards.name: Disenchant
cards.text: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.
cards.flavor:
"The tools of evil are mere things. And like all things, they cannot last forever."
—Song of All, canto 881

rulings.text: This is not modal. If the target changes from an artifact to an enchantment or vice versa, this still destroys it.

cards.originalText: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.

cards.name: Fencing Ace
cards.text: Double strike (This creature deals both first-strike and regular combat damage.)
cards.flavor: His prowess gives the guildless hope that they can hold out against tyranny.
cards.originalText: Double strike

cards.name: Fiend Hunter
cards.text:
When Fiend Hunter enters the battlefield, you may exile another target creature.
When Fiend Hunter leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to the battlefield under its owner's control.

rulings.text: If Fiend Hunter leaves the battlefield before its first ability has resolved, its second ability will trigger and do nothing. Then its first ability will resolve and exile the targeted creature indefinitely.

Once the exiled permanent returns, it's considered a new object with no relation to the object that it was. Auras attached to the exiled permanent will be put into their owners' graveyards. Equipment attached to the exiled permanent will become unattached and remain on the battlefield. Any counters on the exiled permanent will cease to exist.
If a token is exiled this way, it won't return to the battlefield.

cards.originalText:
When Fiend Hunter enters the battlefield, you may exile another target creature.
When Fiend Hunter leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to the battlefield under its owner's control.

cards.name: Geist of the Moors
cards.text: Flying
cards.flavor:
"The battle is won. There's work to be done. / The Blessed Sleep must wait. / A fiend is about. It stalks the devout. / I'll save them from my fate."
—"The Good Geist's Vow"
cards.originalText: Flying

cards.name: Gods Willing
cards.text: Target creature you control gains protection from the color of your choice until end of turn. Scry 1. (Look at the top card of your library. You may put that card on the bottom of your library.)
cards.flavor: Honor the gods of Theros, and they will return the favor.

rulings.text: You choose the color as Gods Willing resolves. Once the color is chosen, it's too late for players to respond.

When you scry, you may put all the cards you look at back on top of your library, you may put all of those cards on the bottom of your library, or you may put some of those cards on top and the rest of them on the bottom.
You choose how to order cards returned to your library after scrying no matter where you put them.
You perform the actions stated on a card in sequence. For some spells and abilities, that means you'll scry last. For others, that means you'll scry and then perform other actions.

Scry appears on some spells and abilities with one or more targets. If all of the spell or ability's targets are illegal when it tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. You won't scry.

cards.originalText: Target creature you control gains protection from the color of your choice until end of turn. Scry 1.

cards.name: Griffin Protector
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, Griffin Protector gets +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: The drums of war stir the hearts of all who fight for righteousness.

rulings.text: If Griffin Protector enters the battlefield under your control at the same time as other creatures, its ability will trigger once for each of those creatures.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, Griffin Protector gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Karona's Zealot
cards.text:
Morph {3}{W}{W} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Karona's Zealot is turned face up, all damage that would be dealt to it this turn is dealt to target creature instead.

rulings.text: If the target creature leaves the battlefield or stops being a creature before damage would be dealt, that damage is not redirected. For example, if you choose a 1/1 creature, then Karona's Zealot would be dealt 3 damage, all 3 is dealt instead to the 1/1 creature, which then dies. If Karona's Zealot would be dealt 3 damage again later in the turn, the 1/1 creature is no longer on the battlefield, so the damage is not redirected.

If multiple replacement effects would modify how damage would be dealt, the player being dealt damage (or the controller of the permanent being dealt damage) chooses the order in which to apply those effects.

cards.originalText:
Morph {3}{W}{W} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Karona's Zealot is turned face up, all damage that would be dealt to it this turn is dealt to target creature instead.

cards.name: Knight of the Skyward Eye
cards.text: {3}{G}: Knight of the Skyward Eye gets +3/+3 until end of turn. Activate this ability only once each turn.
cards.flavor: The Order of the Skyward Eye does the bidding of an evil force, unwittingly stirring fear and mistrust across Bant in accordance with his plans.
cards.originalText: {3}{G}: Knight of the Skyward Eye gets +3/+3 until end of turn. Activate this ability only once each turn.

cards.name: Kongming, "Sleeping Dragon"
cards.text: Other creatures you control get +1/+1.
cards.flavor:
"Such a lord as this—all virtues' height—
Had never been, nor ever was again."
cards.originalText: Other creatures you control get +1/+1.

cards.name: Kor Firewalker
cards.text:
Protection from red
Whenever a player casts a red spell, you may gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: "A river of lava is just another river to cross."

rulings.text: Kor Firewalker's triggered ability resolves before the red spell that caused it to trigger.

cards.originalText:
Protection from red
Whenever a player casts a red spell, you may gain 1 life.

cards.name: Loyal Sentry
cards.text: When Loyal Sentry blocks a creature, destroy that creature and Loyal Sentry.
cards.flavor: His watch ends only when he does.

rulings.text: Loyal Sentry and the creature it blocks are destroyed before combat damage is dealt. The blocked creature is destroyed even if Loyal Sentry leaves the battlefield before its triggered ability resolves.

cards.originalText: When Loyal Sentry blocks a creature, destroy that creature and Loyal Sentry.

cards.name: Luminarch Ascension
cards.text:
At the beginning of each opponent's end step, if you didn't lose life this turn, you may put a quest counter on Luminarch Ascension. (Damage causes loss of life.)
{1}{W}: Create a 4/4 white Angel creature token with flying. Activate this ability only if Luminarch Ascension has four or more quest counters on it.

rulings.text: Luminarch Ascension's first ability doesn't trigger if you have lost life before an opponent's end step begins. If it does trigger but you lose life before it resolves, it does nothing and you won't put a quest counter on Luminarch Ascension.

Luminarch Ascension's first ability cares only whether you lost life this turn, even if Luminarch Ascension wasn't on the battlefield when that happened. It doesn't care how much you lost, whether you also gained life, or even whether you gained more life than you lost.
You can activate Luminarch Ascension's last ability during the end step in which it receives its fourth quest counter.

In a Two-Headed Giant game, Luminarch Ascension's first ability will trigger twice at the beginning of the opposing team's end step if you didn't lose life that turn. It doesn't matter whether your teammate lost life or not.

cards.originalText:
At the beginning of each opponent's end step, if you didn't lose life this turn, you may put a quest counter on Luminarch Ascension.
{1}{W}: Create a 4/4 white Angel creature token with flying. Activate this ability only if Luminarch Ascension has four or more quest counters on it.

cards.name: Lunarch Mantle
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 and has "{1}, Sacrifice a permanent: This creature gains flying until end of turn."
cards.flavor:
"A boon from the angels should never be cast aside."
—Manfried Ulmach, Chief Inquisitor

rulings.text: Only the player who controls the enchanted creature can activate the ability it gains from Lunarch Mantle. This might not be the controller of Lunarch Mantle.

You can activate the ability Lunarch Mantle grants to your enchanted creature by sacrificing any permanent you control, including Lunarch Mantle or the enchanted creature itself. If you sacrifice Lunarch Mantle this way, the creature it previously enchanted still gains flying.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 and has "{1}, Sacrifice a permanent: This creature gains flying until end of turn."

cards.name: Noble Templar
cards.text:
Vigilance
Plainscycling {2} ({2}, Discard this card: Search your library for a Plains card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.)
cards.originalText:
Vigilance
Plainscycling {2} ({2}, Discard this card: Search your library for a Plains card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.)

cards.name: Nyx-Fleece Ram
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: The gods are fascinated by innocence, perhaps because it's a quality they themselves lack.
cards.originalText: At the beginning of your upkeep, you gain 1 life.

cards.name: Ordeal of Heliod
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Whenever enchanted creature attacks, put a +1/+1 counter on it. Then if it has three or more +1/+1 counters on it, sacrifice Ordeal of Heliod.
When you sacrifice Ordeal of Heliod, you gain 10 life.

rulings.text: The +1/+1 counter is put on the creature before blockers are declared and before combat damage is dealt.

The check of whether the enchanted creature has three or more +1/+1 counters on it happens as part of the resolution of the attack triggered ability. If the third +1/+1 counter is put on the enchanted creature any other way, you won't sacrifice the Ordeal until the next time the creature attacks.
If you sacrifice the Ordeal in some other way, its last ability will trigger.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Whenever enchanted creature attacks, put a +1/+1 counter on it. Then if it has three or more +1/+1 counters on it, sacrifice Ordeal of Heliod.
When you sacrifice Ordeal of Heliod, you gain 10 life.

cards.name: Pacifism
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block.
cards.flavor: For the first time in his life, Grakk felt a little warm and fuzzy inside.
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block.

cards.name: Path of Peace
cards.text: Destroy target creature. Its owner gains 4 life.
cards.flavor: As Hedrax stepped into oblivion, he welcomed the unwavering silence.

rulings.text: You are a creature's owner if the card representing it began the game in your deck, or if it's a token that entered the battlefield under your control. If Path of Peace targets a creature that you own but an opponent controls, you'll gain 4 life.
If the target creature is an illegal target by the time Path of Peace tries to resolve, the spell doesn't resolve. No player gains life.

cards.originalText: Destroy target creature. Its owner gains 4 life.

cards.name: Promise of Bunrei
cards.text: When a creature you control dies, sacrifice Promise of Bunrei. If you do, create four 1/1 colorless Spirit creature tokens.
cards.flavor: "I am not afraid to die today nor afraid of what death will bring."

rulings.text: Promise of Bunrei's ability will trigger multiple times if multiple creatures die at once, but it will only be sacrificed once. You'll get only four Spirit tokens.

cards.originalText: When a creature you control dies, sacrifice Promise of Bunrei. If you do, create four 1/1 colorless Spirit creature tokens.

cards.name: Renewed Faith
cards.text:
You gain 6 life.
Cycling {1}{W} ({1}{W}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Renewed Faith, you may gain 2 life.
cards.flavor: Skepticism fades in the face of the miraculous.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you'll draw a card.
Some cards with cycling have an ability that triggers when you cycle them. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
Triggered abilities from cycling a card and the cycling ability itself aren't spells. Effects that interact with spells (such as that of Cancel) won't affect them.

You can cycle a card even if it has a triggered ability from cycling that won't have a legal target. This is because the cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. This also means that if either ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Disallow, for example, or if the triggered ability's targets have become illegal), the other ability will still resolve.

There are many important moments in the story, but the most crucial—called "story spotlights"—are shown on cards. These cards have the Planeswalker symbol in their text box; this symbol has no effect on gameplay. You can read more about these events in the official Magic fiction at http://www.mtgstory.com.

cards.originalText:
You gain 6 life.
Cycling {1}{W} ({1}{W}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Renewed Faith, you may gain 2 life.

cards.name: Rest in Peace
cards.text:
When Rest in Peace enters the battlefield, exile all cards from all graveyards.
If a card or token would be put into a graveyard from anywhere, exile it instead.
cards.flavor: Some corpses the Golgari cannot claim. Some souls the Orzhov cannot shackle.

rulings.text: While Rest in Peace is on the battlefield, abilities that trigger whenever a creature dies won't trigger because cards and tokens are never put into a player's graveyard.
If Rest in Peace is destroyed by a spell, Rest in Peace will be exiled and then the spell will be put into its owner's graveyard.

If a card is discarded while Rest in Peace is on the battlefield, abilities that function when a card is discarded (such as madness) still work, even though that card never reaches a graveyard. In addition, spells or abilities that check the characteristics of a discarded card (such as Chandra Ablaze's first ability) can find that card in exile.

cards.originalText:
When Rest in Peace enters the battlefield, exile all cards from all graveyards.
If a card or token would be put into a graveyard from anywhere, exile it instead.

cards.name: Savannah Lions
cards.flavor:
"One alone is fearsome; one among many is unstoppable."
—Benalish proverb

cards.name: Squadron Hawk
cards.text:
Flying
When Squadron Hawk enters the battlefield, you may search your library for up to three cards named Squadron Hawk, reveal them, put them into your hand, then shuffle your library.
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Squadron Hawk enters the battlefield, you may search your library for up to three cards named Squadron Hawk, reveal them, put them into your hand, then shuffle your library.

cards.name: Swords to Plowshares
cards.text: Exile target creature. Its controller gains life equal to its power.

rulings.text: The amount of life gained is equal to the power of the targeted creature as it last existed on the battlefield.
If the creature's power is negative, its controller doesn't lose or gain life.

cards.originalText: Exile target creature. Its controller gains life equal to its power.

cards.name: Thalia, Guardian of Thraben
cards.text:
First strike
Noncreature spells cost {1} more to cast.
cards.flavor: "Thraben is our home and I will not see it fall to this unhallowed horde."

rulings.text: Thalia's ability affects each spell that's not a creature spell, including your own.

To determine the total cost of a spell, start with the mana cost or alternative cost you're paying, add any cost increases, then apply any cost reductions. The converted mana cost of the spell remains unchanged, no matter what the total cost to cast it was.

foreignNames.name: スレイベンの守護者、サリア

cards.originalText:
First strike
Noncreature spells cost {1} more to cast.

cards.name: Urbis Protector
cards.text: When Urbis Protector enters the battlefield, create a 4/4 white Angel creature token with flying.
cards.flavor:
"Guilds be damned. We can fend for ourselves."
—Vennick of the Gateless
cards.originalText: When Urbis Protector enters the battlefield, create a 4/4 white Angel creature token with flying.

cards.name: Valor in Akros
cards.text: Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under your control, creatures you control get +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: There's no stronger armor than the bravery of those beside you.

rulings.text: Valor in Akros's ability affects only creatures you control at the time the ability resolves, including the creature that caused it to trigger. Creatures you begin to control later in the turn won't get +1/+1.

cards.originalText: Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under your control, creatures you control get +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Whitemane Lion
cards.text:
Flash (You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.)
When Whitemane Lion enters the battlefield, return a creature you control to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: Saltfield nomads call a sudden storm a "whitemane."

rulings.text: You may return this creature itself to its owner's hand as its triggered ability resolves. If you don't control enough other creatures, you must return it.
The ability doesn't target any creature. You don't choose what to return until the ability resolves. Once the ability has started to resolve, no one can respond to the choice.

foreignNames.name: 白たてがみのライオン

cards.originalText:
Flash
When Whitemane Lion enters the battlefield, return a creature you control to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Accumulated Knowledge
cards.text: Draw a card, then draw cards equal to the number of cards named Accumulated Knowledge in all graveyards.
cards.flavor:
"I have seen and heard much here. There are secrets within secrets. Let me show you."
—Takara, to Eladamri

rulings.text: Because Accumulated Knowledge is still on the stack as you perform its instructions, it isn't in your graveyard and won't add to the number of cards drawn.

cards.originalText: Draw a card, then draw cards equal to the number of cards named Accumulated Knowledge in all graveyards.

cards.name: Arcane Denial
cards.text:
Counter target spell. Its controller may draw up to two cards at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.
You draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.

rulings.text: The controller of the countered spell doesn't choose how many cards to draw until the relevant ability resolves. The player may draw 0, 1, or 2 cards. They choose the number before drawing any cards.

cards.originalText:
Counter target spell. Its controller may draw up to two cards at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.
You draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.

cards.name: Bident of Thassa
cards.text:
Whenever a creature you control deals combat damage to a player, you may draw a card.
{1}{U}, {T}: Creatures your opponents control attack this turn if able.
cards.flavor: The wills of mortals shift as the tide ebbs and flows.

rulings.text: The controller of each attacking creature still chooses which player or planeswalker that creature attacks.

If a creature can't attack for any reason (such as being tapped or having come under that player's control that turn), then it doesn't attack. If there's a cost associated with having a creature attack, the player isn't forced to pay that cost, so it doesn't have to attack in that case either.

cards.originalText:
Whenever a creature you control deals combat damage to a player, you may draw a card.
{1}{U}, {T}: Creatures your opponents control attack this turn if able.

cards.name: Blue Elemental Blast
cards.text:
Choose one —
• Counter target red spell.
• Destroy target red permanent.
cards.flavor: Nothing escapes a sharp mind.

rulings.text: The decision to counter a spell or destroy a permanent is a decision made on announcement before the target is selected. If the spell is redirected, this mode can't be changed, so only targets of the selected type are valid.

cards.originalText:
Choose one —
• Counter target red spell.
• Destroy target red permanent.

cards.name: Blue Sun's Zenith
cards.text: Target player draws X cards. Shuffle Blue Sun's Zenith into its owner's library.
cards.flavor:
"The Origin Query will wait. We must ensure we survive to return to it."
—Pelyus, vedalken ordinar

rulings.text: If this spell doesn't resolve, none of its effects occur. In particular, it will go to the graveyard rather than to its owner's library.
Because you follow the spell's instructions in order, you won't be able to draw the same Blue Sun's Zenith that you cast.

cards.originalText: Target player draws X cards. Shuffle Blue Sun's Zenith into its owner's library.

cards.name: Borrowing 100,000 Arrows
cards.text: Draw a card for each tapped creature target opponent controls.
cards.flavor: Kongming and Lu Su tricked Wei troops into shooting over 100,000 arrows at them to later use against the Wei at Red Cliffs.
cards.originalText: Draw a card for each tapped creature target opponent controls.

cards.name: Brainstorm
cards.text: Draw three cards, then put two cards from your hand on top of your library in any order.

rulings.text: You draw three cards and put two cards back all while Brainstorm is resolving. Nothing can happen between the two, and no player may choose to take actions.

cards.originalText: Draw three cards, then put two cards from your hand on top of your library in any order.

cards.name: Brine Elemental
cards.text:
Morph {5}{U}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Brine Elemental is turned face up, each opponent skips their next untap step.
cards.flavor: Water calls to water, and the world is left exhausted and withered in its wake.

rulings.text: Skipping your "next" untap step is cumulative. If a player turns two Brine Elementals face up on the same turn, that player's opponents will each skip their next two untap steps.

cards.originalText:
Morph {5}{U}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Brine Elemental is turned face up, each opponent skips his or her next untap step.

cards.name: Choking Tethers
cards.text:
Tap up to four target creatures.
Cycling {1}{U} ({1}{U}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Choking Tethers, you may tap target creature.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you'll draw a card.
You can cycle this card even if there are no targets for the triggered ability. That's because the cycling ability itself has no targets.

cards.originalText:
Tap up to four target creatures.
Cycling {1}{U} ({1}{U}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Choking Tethers, you may tap target creature.

cards.name: Coralhelm Guide
cards.text: {4}{U}: Target creature can't be blocked this turn.
cards.flavor:
"She knows every step of this coastline, both above and below the surface, and she has hideouts all along the way. She will get you there."
—Jori En, expedition leader

rulings.text: Activating Coralhelm Guide's ability after a creature has become blocked won't cause that creature to become unblocked.

cards.originalText: {4}{U}: Target creature can't be blocked this turn.

cards.name: Counterspell
cards.text: Counter target spell.
cards.originalText: Counter target spell.

cards.name: Court Hussar
cards.text:
Vigilance
When Court Hussar enters the battlefield, look at the top three cards of your library, then put one of them into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.
When Court Hussar enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless {W} was spent to cast it.

rulings.text: If this enters the battlefield in a way other than announcing it as a spell, then the appropriate mana can't have been paid, and you'll have to sacrifice it.

cards.originalText:
Vigilance
When Court Hussar enters the battlefield, look at the top three cards of your library, then put one of them into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.
When Court Hussar enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless {W} was spent to cast it.

cards.name: Curiosity
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Whenever enchanted creature deals damage to an opponent, you may draw a card.
cards.flavor: All Mirri wanted to do was rest, but she couldn't ignore a nagging suspicion as she followed Crovax's skulking form.

rulings.text: "You" refers to the controller of Curiosity, which may be different from the controller of the enchanted creature. "An opponent" refers to an opponent of Curiosity's controller.
Any damage dealt by the enchanted creature to an opponent will cause Curiosity to trigger, not just combat damage.
Curiosity doesn't trigger if the enchanted creature deals damage to a planeswalker controlled by an opponent.
You draw one card each time the enchanted creature deals damage to an opponent, no matter how much damage it deals or whether it was dealt in combat.
If this Aura enchants an opponent's creature, you won't draw a card when that creature damages you. The creature has to deal damage to one of your opponents for the ability to trigger.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Whenever enchanted creature deals damage to an opponent, you may draw a card.

cards.name: Cursecatcher
cards.text: Sacrifice Cursecatcher: Counter target instant or sorcery spell unless its controller pays {1}.
cards.flavor: "Of all the things that can be stolen, opportunity is the most valuable."
cards.originalText: Sacrifice Cursecatcher: Counter target instant or sorcery spell unless its controller pays {1}.

cards.name: Dragon's Eye Savants
cards.text:
Morph—Reveal a blue card in your hand. (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Dragon's Eye Savants is turned face up, look at target opponent's hand.

rulings.text: Morph lets you cast a card face down by paying {3}, and lets you turn the face-down permanent face up any time you have priority by paying its morph cost.

The face-down spell has no mana cost and has a converted mana cost of 0. When you cast a face-down spell, put it on the stack face down so no other player knows what it is, and pay {3}. This is an alternative cost.

When the spell resolves, it enters the battlefield as a 2/2 creature with no name, mana cost, creature types, or abilities. It's colorless and has a converted mana cost of 0. Other effects that apply to the creature can still grant it any of these characteristics.

Any time you have priority, you may turn the face-down creature face up by revealing what its morph cost is and paying that cost. This is a special action. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to. Only a face-down permanent can be turned face up this way; a face-down spell cannot.
Because the permanent is on the battlefield both before and after it's turned face up, turning a permanent face up doesn't cause any enters-the-battlefield abilities to trigger.

A permanent that turns face up or face down changes characteristics but is otherwise the same permanent. Spells and abilities that were targeting that permanent, as well as Auras and Equipment that were attached to the permanent, aren't affected.
At any time, you can look at a face-down spell or permanent you control. You can't look at face-down spells or permanents you don't control unless an effect instructs you to do so.

You must ensure that your face-down spells and permanents can easily be differentiated from each other. You're not allowed to mix up the cards that represent them on the battlefield in order to confuse other players. The order they entered the battlefield should remain clear. Common methods for doing this include using markers or dice, or simply placing them in order on the battlefield.
If a face-down permanent leaves the battlefield, you must reveal it. You must also reveal all face-down spells and permanents you control if you leave the game or if the game ends.

cards.originalText:
Morph—Reveal a blue card in your hand. (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Dragon's Eye Savants is turned face up, look at target opponent's hand.

cards.name: Exclude
cards.text:
Counter target creature spell.
Draw a card.
cards.flavor:
"Terrifying, but thankfully temporary."
—Teferi

rulings.text: Exclude can target a creature spell that can't be countered. When Exclude resolves, that spell won't be countered, but you'll still draw a card.

cards.originalText:
Counter target creature spell.
Draw a card.

cards.name: Fathom Seer
cards.text:
Morph—Return two Islands you control to their owner's hand. (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Fathom Seer is turned face up, draw two cards.
cards.originalText:
Morph—Return two Islands you control to their owner's hand. (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Fathom Seer is turned face up, draw two cards.

cards.name: Flash
cards.text: You may put a creature card from your hand onto the battlefield. If you do, sacrifice it unless you pay its mana cost reduced by up to {2}.
cards.flavor: No tactic transforms a battle like a well-timed carnivore.

rulings.text: If the creature has {X} in its mana cost, X is considered to be 0.
Only the generic mana in that creature's mana cost is reduced. For example, if that creature's mana cost is {1}{R}, you'll have to pay {R} to keep it.
The creature enters the battlefield, so it will trigger enters-the-battlefield abilities even if you choose not to pay.

If you choose not to pay, the creature is sacrificed immediately. No player will get priority in between the creature entering the battlefield and being sacrificed. Sacrificing the creature this way will trigger any abilities that trigger when it leaves the battlefield, and those abilities will be put onto the stack at the same time as those that triggered when it entered the battlefield.

cards.originalText: You may put a creature card from your hand onto the battlefield. If you do, sacrifice it unless you pay its mana cost reduced by up to {2}.

cards.name: Freed from the Real
cards.text:
Enchant creature
{U}: Tap enchanted creature.
{U}: Untap enchanted creature.
cards.flavor: When a strong mind moves, form and energy shift to heed it.

rulings.text: Only the player who controls Freed from the Real can activate its abilities. This might not be the controller of the enchanted creature.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
{U}: Tap enchanted creature.
{U}: Untap enchanted creature.

cards.name: Genju of the Falls
cards.text:
Enchant Island
{2}: Enchanted Island becomes a 3/2 blue Spirit creature with flying until end of turn. It's still a land.
When enchanted Island is put into a graveyard, you may return Genju of the Falls from your graveyard to your hand.

rulings.text: A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

Activating the ability that turns it into a creature while it's already a creature will override any effects that set its power and/or toughness to a specific number. However, any effect that raises or lowers power and/or toughness (such as the effect created by Giant Growth, Glorious Anthem, or a +1/+1 counter) will continue to apply.

cards.originalText:
Enchant Island
{2}: Enchanted Island becomes a 3/2 blue Spirit creature with flying until end of turn. It's still a land.
When enchanted Island is put into a graveyard, you may return Genju of the Falls from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: Ghost Ship
cards.text:
Flying
{U}{U}{U}: Regenerate Ghost Ship.
cards.flavor: Going down with the ship is just the beginning.
cards.originalText:
Flying
{U}{U}{U}: Regenerate Ghost Ship.

cards.name: Horseshoe Crab
cards.text: {U}: Untap Horseshoe Crab.
cards.flavor: In the final days before the disaster, all the crabs on Tolaria migrated from inlets, streams, and ponds back to the sea. No one took note.
cards.originalText: {U}: Untap Horseshoe Crab.

cards.name: Jace, the Mind Sculptor
cards.text:
+2: Look at the top card of target player's library. You may put that card on the bottom of that player's library.
0: Draw three cards, then put two cards from your hand on top of your library in any order.
−1: Return target creature to its owner's hand.
−12: Exile all cards from target player's library, then that player shuffles their hand into their library.

rulings.text: You draw three cards and put two cards back all while Jace's second ability is resolving. Nothing can happen between the two, and no player may choose to take actions.

If the targeted player for Jace's last ability has no cards in hand, that player shuffles nothing into their library, and that player's library will remain empty. That player won't lose the game until they try to draw from the empty library.

foreignNames.name: 精神を刻む者、ジェイス

cards.originalText:
+2: Look at the top card of target player's library. You may put that card on the bottom of that player's library.
0: Draw three cards, then put two cards from your hand on top of your library in any order.
−1: Return target creature to its owner's hand.
−12: Exile all cards from target player's library, then that player shuffles his or her hand into his or her library.

cards.name: Jalira, Master Polymorphist
cards.text: {2}{U}, {T}, Sacrifice another creature: Reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a nonlegendary creature card. Put that card onto the battlefield and the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order.
cards.flavor: "You can become anything if I just put my mind to it."

rulings.text: If your library has no nonlegendary creature cards in it, you'll reveal all the cards in your library, then put them in a random order. Although this is not technically shuffling your library, no player is allowed to know the order of those cards and you will randomize the cards in your deck.

foreignNames.name: 練達の変身術士、ジャリラ

cards.originalText: {2}{U}, {T}, Sacrifice another creature: Reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a nonlegendary creature card. Put that card onto the battlefield and the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order.

cards.name: Man-o'-War
cards.text: When Man-o'-War enters the battlefield, return target creature to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor:
"Beauty to the eye does not always translate to the touch."
—Naimah, Femeref philosopher

rulings.text: If there are no other creatures on the battlefield when Man-o'-War enters the battlefield, its ability must target itself.

cards.originalText: When Man-o'-War enters the battlefield, return target creature to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Merfolk Looter
cards.text: {T}: Draw a card, then discard a card.
cards.flavor: Merfolk don't always know what they're looking for, but they're certain once they find it.

rulings.text: You can't do anything in between drawing a card and discarding a card, including casting or cycling the card you drew.

foreignNames.name: マーフォークの物あさり

cards.originalText: {T}: Draw a card, then discard a card.

cards.name: Murder of Crows
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever another creature dies, you may draw a card. If you do, discard a card.
cards.flavor: Even more than carrion, they crave the last words of the dying.

rulings.text: If another creature dies at the same time as Murder of Crows, its last ability triggers.
You can't do anything in between drawing a card and discarding a card, including casting or cycling the card you drew.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever another creature dies, you may draw a card. If you do, discard a card.

cards.name: Mystic of the Hidden Way
cards.text:
Mystic of the Hidden Way can't be blocked.
Morph {2}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
cards.flavor: "There are no obstacles, only different paths."

rulings.text: Morph lets you cast a card face down by paying {3}, and lets you turn the face-down permanent face up any time you have priority by paying its morph cost.

The face-down spell has no mana cost and has a converted mana cost of 0. When you cast a face-down spell, put it on the stack face down so no other player knows what it is, and pay {3}. This is an alternative cost.

When the spell resolves, it enters the battlefield as a 2/2 creature with no name, mana cost, creature types, or abilities. It's colorless and has a converted mana cost of 0. Other effects that apply to the creature can still grant it any of these characteristics.

Any time you have priority, you may turn the face-down creature face up by revealing what its morph cost is and paying that cost. This is a special action. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to. Only a face-down permanent can be turned face up this way; a face-down spell cannot.
Because the permanent is on the battlefield both before and after it's turned face up, turning a permanent face up doesn't cause any enters-the-battlefield abilities to trigger.

A permanent that turns face up or face down changes characteristics but is otherwise the same permanent. Spells and abilities that were targeting that permanent, as well as Auras and Equipment that were attached to the permanent, aren't affected.
At any time, you can look at a face-down spell or permanent you control. You can't look at face-down spells or permanents you don't control unless an effect instructs you to do so.

You must ensure that your face-down spells and permanents can easily be differentiated from each other. You're not allowed to mix up the cards that represent them on the battlefield in order to confuse other players. The order they entered the battlefield should remain clear. Common methods for doing this include using markers or dice, or simply placing them in order on the battlefield.
If a face-down permanent leaves the battlefield, you must reveal it. You must also reveal all face-down spells and permanents you control if you leave the game or if the game ends.
If a face-down Mystic of the Hidden Way is blocked and then turned face up, it stays blocked.

cards.originalText:
Mystic of the Hidden Way can't be blocked.
Morph {2}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)

cards.name: Pact of Negation
cards.text:
Counter target spell.
At the beginning of your next upkeep, pay {3}{U}{U}. If you don't, you lose the game.
cards.flavor: Those who expect betrayal at every turn are seldom disappointed.

rulings.text: Although originally printed with a characteristic-defining ability that defined its color, this card now has a color indicator. This color indicator can't be affected by text-changing effects (such as the one created by Crystal Spray), although color-changing effects can still overwrite it.

cards.originalText:
Counter target spell.
At the beginning of your next upkeep, pay {3}{U}{U}. If you don't, you lose the game.

cards.name: Phantasmal Bear
cards.text: When Phantasmal Bear becomes the target of a spell or ability, sacrifice it.
cards.flavor:
"You know it to be false, but when its claws find you, what you know won't matter much at all."
—Pol Jamaar, illusionist

rulings.text: If Phantasmal Bear becomes the target of a spell or ability, its ability triggers and goes on the stack on top of that spell or ability. The ability will resolve first (causing Phantasmal Bear to be sacrificed). Unless the spell or ability has another target, it will then be countered when it tries to resolve for having no legal targets.

cards.originalText: When Phantasmal Bear becomes the target of a spell or ability, sacrifice it.

cards.name: Reef Worm
cards.text: When Reef Worm dies, create a 3/3 blue Fish creature token with "When this creature dies, create a 6/6 blue Whale creature token with 'When this creature dies, create a 9/9 blue Kraken creature token.'"
cards.originalText: When Reef Worm dies, create a 3/3 blue Fish creature token with "When this creature dies, create a 6/6 blue Whale creature token with ‘When this creature dies, create a 9/9 blue Kraken creature token.'"

cards.name: Retraction Helix
cards.text: Until end of turn, target creature gains "{T}: Return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand."
cards.flavor: Where the geometries of the world collapse, a master of the aether can harvest power beyond comprehending.
cards.originalText: Until end of turn, target creature gains "{T}: Return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand."

cards.text:
Flying
Islandcycling {2} ({2}, Discard this card: Search your library for an Island card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.)

Islandcycling {2} ({2}, Discard this card: Search your library for an Island card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.)

cards.name: Sift
cards.text: Draw three cards, then discard a card.
cards.flavor:
"Twice I have let the Legacy slip away. Never again."
—Karn, silver golem
cards.originalText: Draw three cards, then discard a card.

cards.name: Totally Lost
cards.text: Put target nonland permanent on top of its owner's library.
cards.flavor: Fblthp had always hated crowds.
cards.originalText: Put target nonland permanent on top of its owner's library.

cards.name: Twisted Image
cards.text:
Switch target creature's power and toughness until end of turn.
Draw a card.
cards.flavor:
"True strength is in the mind, for the body is too malleable a form."
—Politus, vedalken emisar

rulings.text: Effects that switch power and toughness apply after all other effects that change power and/or toughness, regardless of which effect was created first.
Switching a creature's power and toughness twice (or any even number of times) effectively returns the creature to the power and toughness it had before any switches.

cards.originalText:
Switch target creature's power and toughness until end of turn.
Draw a card.

cards.name: Vendilion Clique
cards.text:
Flash
Flying
When Vendilion Clique enters the battlefield, look at target player's hand. You may choose a nonland card from it. If you do, that player reveals the chosen card, puts it on the bottom of their library, then draws a card.

foreignNames.name: ヴェンディリオン三人衆

cards.originalText:
Flash
Flying
When Vendilion Clique enters the battlefield, look at target player's hand. You may choose a nonland card from it. If you do, that player reveals the chosen card, puts it on the bottom of his or her library, then draws a card.

cards.name: Vesuvan Shapeshifter
cards.text:
As Vesuvan Shapeshifter enters the battlefield or is turned face up, you may choose another creature on the battlefield. If you do, until Vesuvan Shapeshifter is turned face down, it becomes a copy of that creature, except it has "At the beginning of your upkeep, you may turn this creature face down."
Morph {1}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)

rulings.text: Vesuvan Shapeshifter's ability to become a copy is a replacement effect. Because turning a creature face up and applying replacement effects both don't use the stack, players won't be able to take actions between the time you announce that you're turning Vesuvan Shapeshifter face up and the time it has become a copy of the creature of your choice.

Vesuvan Shapeshifter copies exactly what was printed on the original creature (unless that creature is copying something else or is a token; see below). It doesn't copy whether that creature is tapped or untapped, whether it has any counters on it or Auras attached to it, or any non-copy effects that have changed its power, toughness, types, color, or so on.
If the chosen creature has {X} in its mana cost, X is considered to be 0.
If the chosen creature is copying something else (for example, if the chosen creature is another Vesuvan Shapeshifter), then Vesuvan Shapeshifter copies whatever the chosen creature copied.

If the chosen creature is a token, Vesuvan Shapeshifter copies the original characteristics of that token as stated by the effect that created the token. Vesuvan Shapeshifter is not a token in this case.

Any enters-the-battlefield abilities of the copied creature will trigger when Vesuvan Shapeshifter enters the battlefield. Any "as [this creature] enters the battlefield" or "[this creature] enters the battlefield with" abilities of the chosen creature will also work as it enters the battlefield. Similarly, any "[when/as] [this creature] is turned face up" abilities of the chosen creature will work if Vesuvan Shapeshifter is turned face up.

If Vesuvan Shapeshifter somehow enters the battlefield at the same time as another creature, Vesuvan Shapeshifter can't become a copy of that creature. You may only choose a creature that's already on the battlefield.
When Vesuvan Shapeshifter is turned face down, its copy effect wears off. While it's face down, it's a 2/2 face-down Vesuvan Shapeshifter that can be turned face up for a morph cost of {1}{U}.

If another creature copies Vesuvan Shapeshifter while it's face up and copying another creature, the new creature will become a copy of whatever Vesuvan Shapeshifter is copying and gain the "you may turn this creature face down" ability. It won't gain morph {1}{U}. If that creature is then turned face down, its copy effect will continue and it'll be a face-down version of whatever it's copying. If the creature it's copying has morph, it can be turned face up. If the creature it's copying doesn't have morph, it's stuck face down.
If Vesuvan Shapeshifter copies a face-down creature, it becomes a face-up 2/2 colorless, nameless creature with no abilities other than the one it gives itself.

foreignNames.name: ヴェズーヴァの多相の戦士

cards.originalText:
As Vesuvan Shapeshifter enters the battlefield or is turned face up, you may choose another creature on the battlefield. If you do, until Vesuvan Shapeshifter is turned face down, it becomes a copy of that creature and gains "At the beginning of your upkeep, you may turn this creature face down."
Morph {1}{U}

cards.name: Willbender
cards.text:
Morph {1}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Willbender is turned face up, change the target of target spell or ability with a single target.

rulings.text: The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.

If a spell with split second is on the stack, you can still respond by turning this creature face up and targeting that spell with the trigger. This is because split second only stops players from casting spells or activating abilities, while turning a creature face up is a special action.

You don't choose the new target for the spell until Willbender's triggered ability resolves. You must change the target if possible. However, you can't change the target to an illegal target. If there are no legal targets to choose from, the target isn't changed. It doesn't matter if the original target of that spell has somehow become illegal itself.
If a spell or ability targets multiple things, you can't target it with Willbender's triggered ability, even if all but one of those targets have become illegal.
If a spell or ability targets the same player or object multiple times, you can't target it with Willbender's ability.

cards.originalText:
Morph {1}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Willbender is turned face up, change the target of target spell or ability with a single target.

cards.name: Ancient Craving
cards.text: You draw three cards and you lose 3 life.
cards.flavor: Knowledge demands sacrifice.
cards.originalText: You draw three cards and you lose 3 life.

cards.name: Bloodhunter Bat
cards.text:
Flying
When Bloodhunter Bat enters the battlefield, target player loses 2 life and you gain 2 life.
cards.flavor: It returns eager to share the feast of blood and gore with its ghoulish master.
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Bloodhunter Bat enters the battlefield, target player loses 2 life and you gain 2 life.

cards.name: Caustic Tar
cards.text:
Enchant land
Enchanted land has "{T}: Target player loses 3 life."
cards.flavor: The spite of the Cabal turns meadow into mire.
cards.originalText:
Enchant land
Enchanted land has "{T}: Target player loses 3 life."

cards.name: Dark Ritual
cards.text: Add {B}{B}{B}.
cards.originalText: Add {B}{B}{B} to your mana pool.

cards.name: Deadly Designs
cards.text:
{2}: Put a plot counter on Deadly Designs. Any player may activate this ability.
When there are five or more plot counters on Deadly Designs, sacrifice it. If you do, destroy up to two target creatures.

rulings.text: You control the last ability of Deadly Designs, no matter who activated the ability to give it its fifth plot counter.
You must sacrifice Deadly Designs as its last ability resolves. However, you can choose zero creatures as targets if you want.

If the player who controlled Deadly Designs as its last ability triggered doesn't control it as that ability resolves, Deadly Designs won't be sacrificed. The same is true if each of the ability's targets are all illegal by the time the ability resolves. However, if it's still on the battlefield and has five or more plot counters on it, its last ability will immediately trigger again.

cards.originalText:
{2}: Put a plot counter on Deadly Designs. Any player may activate this ability.
When there are five or more plot counters on Deadly Designs, sacrifice it. If you do, destroy up to two target creatures.

cards.name: Death's-Head Buzzard
cards.text:
Flying
When Death's-Head Buzzard dies, all creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Infested with vermin, ever hungering, dropping from night's sky.

rulings.text: The last ability of Death's-Head Buzzard affects only creatures on the battlefield at the time it resolves. Creatures that enter the battlefield later in the turn won't get -1/-1.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Death's-Head Buzzard dies, all creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Diabolic Edict
cards.text: Target player sacrifices a creature.
cards.originalText: Target player sacrifices a creature.

cards.name: Dirge of Dread
cards.text:
All creatures gain fear until end of turn. (They can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or black creatures.)
Cycling {1}{B} ({1}{B}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Dirge of Dread, you may have target creature gain fear until end of turn.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you'll draw a card.
You can cycle this card even if there are no targets for the triggered ability. That's because the cycling ability itself has no targets.

cards.originalText:
All creatures gain fear until end of turn. (They can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or black creatures.)
Cycling {1}{B} ({1}{B}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Dirge of Dread, you may have target creature gain fear until end of turn.

cards.name: Disfigure
cards.text: Target creature gets -2/-2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "Brave scar or unfortunate tale? It all depends on your pain threshold."
cards.originalText: Target creature gets -2/-2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Doomsday
cards.text: Search your library and graveyard for five cards and exile the rest. Put the chosen cards on top of your library in any order. You lose half your life, rounded up.

rulings.text: If your graveyard and library combined contain five or more cards, you must choose five cards from among them. You can't choose to find fewer than that.
If your graveyard and library combined contain fewer than five cards, all of those cards will wind up in your library.

cards.originalText: Search your library and graveyard for five cards and exile the rest. Put the chosen cards on top of your library in any order. You lose half your life, rounded up.

cards.name: Dusk Legion Zealot
cards.text: When Dusk Legion Zealot enters the battlefield, you draw a card and you lose 1 life.
cards.flavor: Once they reached Orazca, the Legion's explorers ransacked tombs and temples, hunting for the Immortal Sun.
cards.originalText: When Dusk Legion Zealot enters the battlefield, you draw a card and you lose 1 life.

cards.name: Erg Raiders
cards.text: At the beginning of your end step, if Erg Raiders didn't attack this turn, Erg Raiders deals 2 damage to you unless it came under your control this turn.
cards.flavor: Their skills are extensive, and their appetite for battle just as vast.

rulings.text: A creature "comes under your control" if it enters the battlefield under your control or if you gain control of it while it's already on the battlefield.

cards.originalText: At the beginning of your end step, if Erg Raiders didn't attack this turn, Erg Raiders deals 2 damage to you unless it came under your control this turn.

cards.name: Fallen Angel
cards.text:
Flying
Sacrifice a creature: Fallen Angel gets +2/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "Why do you weep for the dead? I rejoice, for they have died for me."

rulings.text: Can sacrifice itself.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Sacrifice a creature: Fallen Angel gets +2/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Hell's Caretaker
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice a creature: Return target creature card from your graveyard to the battlefield. Activate this ability only during your upkeep.
cards.flavor: "The rules are clear. If you want to leave, you need only convince another to take your place."

rulings.text: Hell's Caretaker can be the creature sacrificed to activate its ability, but it can't be the target of its own ability.

The upkeep step is before the draw step, after the untap step. Because the turn has already begun, creatures put onto the battlefield during your upkeep won't be able to attack or pay a {T} cost this turn.

cards.originalText: {T}, Sacrifice a creature: Return target creature card from your graveyard to the battlefield. Activate this ability only during your upkeep.

cards.name: Horror of the Broken Lands
cards.text:
Whenever you cycle or discard another card, Horror of the Broken Lands gets +2/+1 until end of turn.
Cycling {B} ({B}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
cards.flavor: It feeds on dry bones in the sand and desperate pleas in the wind.

rulings.text: Some cards have an ability that triggers whenever you cycle any card. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
An ability that triggers whenever you discard a card doesn't give you permission to discard cards. You'll need another effect that instructs or allows you to discard them.

An ability that triggers whenever you "cycle or discard" a card triggers only once if you cycle a card. The ability "Whenever you discard a card" is functionally identical to this ability; cycling is mentioned for clarity.

If a player discards a card during their cleanup step due to having too many cards in hand, any appropriate abilities that trigger on discarding that card trigger. If this happens, those triggered abilities are put onto the stack and players receive priority in that cleanup step to cast spells or activate abilities (normally, no players may take actions during a cleanup step). Another cleanup step is created following that one.

cards.originalText:
Whenever you cycle or discard another card, Horror of the Broken Lands gets +2/+1 until end of turn.
Cycling {B} ({B}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)

cards.name: Laquatus's Champion
cards.text:
When Laquatus's Champion enters the battlefield, target player loses 6 life.
When Laquatus's Champion leaves the battlefield, that player gains 6 life.
{B}: Regenerate Laquatus's Champion.
cards.flavor: Chainer's dark gift to a darker soul.

rulings.text: As Laquatus's Champion's second ability resolves, the player who gains 6 life is the player who was the target of the first ability (or, if that ability is still on the stack, the player who is its target).

foreignNames.name: ラクァタスのチャンピオン

cards.originalText:
When Laquatus's Champion enters the battlefield, target player loses 6 life.
When Laquatus's Champion leaves the battlefield, that player gains 6 life.
{B}: Regenerate Laquatus's Champion.

cards.name: Living Death
cards.text: Each player exiles all creature cards from their graveyard, then sacrifices all creatures they control, then puts all cards they exiled this way onto the battlefield.

rulings.text: As Living Death resolves, all players exile their creature cards from graveyards at the same time. Then all players sacrifice all creatures they control at the same time. Then all players put all creatures they exiled onto the battlefield at the same time.

Only cards exiled by Living Death's first instruction are put onto the battlefield. If a replacement effect (such as that of Leyline of the Void) causes any of the sacrificed creatures to be exiled instead of put into a graveyard, those cards aren't returned to the battlefield.

cards.originalText: Each player exiles all creature cards from his or her graveyard, then sacrifices all creatures he or she controls, then puts all cards he or she exiled this way onto the battlefield.

cards.name: Mesmeric Fiend
cards.text:
When Mesmeric Fiend enters the battlefield, target opponent reveals their hand and you choose a nonland card from it. Exile that card.
When Mesmeric Fiend leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to its owner's hand.

rulings.text: If Mesmeric Fiend leaves the battlefield before its first ability has resolved, its second ability will trigger and do nothing. Then its first ability will resolve and exile a nonland card from the target opponent's hand indefinitely.

cards.originalText:
When Mesmeric Fiend enters the battlefield, target opponent reveals his or her hand and you choose a nonland card from it. Exile that card.
When Mesmeric Fiend leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to its owner's hand.
